Explanations about Options.-P(M):
Specifies the port to connect to on the remote host. Note that this option is
 written with a capital ‘P’, because -p is already reserved for preserving the times
 and modes of the file.
Explanations about Options.-i(M):
Selects the file from which the identity (private key) for public key authentication
 is read. This option is directly passed to ssh(1).

Answers.Most Similar TLDR Task: Use a specific ssh private key for authentication with the remote host

Explanations about Options.-b(C): Adding other keys is quite straightforward  Storing the above file in "copy-id.sftp" and running "sftp -b copy-id.sftp your_host" should do the job.
Explanations about Options.-b(M):
Batch mode reads a series of commands from an input batchfile instead of stdin.
 Since it lacks user interaction it should be used in conjunction with non-
 interactive authentication to obviate the need to enter a password at connection
 time (see sshd(8) and ssh-keygen(1) for details).

Explanations about Options.-s(C): Check your account's actual login shell ("getent passwd $USER" on the server) and adjust if necessary using "chsh -s /bin/bash" (or "chsh -s /bin/zsh" or "chsh -s /bin/ksh93" or "chsh -s /usr/bin/fish" or whatever interactive shell you want to use).
Explanations about Options.-s(M):
The name of the user's new login shell. Setting this field to blank causes the system
 to select the default login shell.
